properties.name: 'Iolani Palace
properties.description: Posted by Igrok 364 S King StThe only royal residence in the U.S.

properties.name: Aiea High School
properties.description: Posted by Igrok 98-1276 Ulune Street, AieaThrough the Aiea/Moanalua Adult School for Continuing Education I enrolled in 10 hula lessons. Y\'all gotta see my kaholo!

properties.name: Ala Moana Mall
properties.description: Posted by Igrok Hawaii\'s largest (outdoor) mall.

properties.name: Aloha Tower Marketplace
properties.description: Posted by Igrok    Honolulu, OahuOnce the tallest structure in Honolulu harbor now a vibrant tourist hotspot. Cruise liners conveniently deposit passengers here where fine dining, upscale clothiers, and tantalizing entertainment garner excellent reviews. Fireworks shows are standard fare and Gordon Biersch will make you believe that french fries, indeed, can be made into a delicacy. Misses: Parking\'s a b*tch! Not much to do for the traveler with little $.

properties.name: Bishop Museum
properties.description: Posted by Igrok 1525 Bernice St, HonoluluFounded in 1889 by Charles Reed Bishop in honor of his late wife, Princess Bernice Pauahi Bishop, the museum contains an impressive collection of Hawaiian artifacts. In conjunction with the planetarium, the museum also hosts throughout the year numerous live webcasts of celestial occurrences such as eclipses. I went to a live webcast sometime in the summer of 2005 in hopes of seeing a brilliant collision between a space probe and comet. The result was, in a word, lame.

properties.name: Blaisdell Center
properties.description: Posted by Igrok  Honolulu, OahuI secured backstage passes to a Honolulu Symphony performance. It was off da chain!

properties.name: Boots and Kimo's
properties.description: Posted by Igrok119 Hekili St, KailuaBring on the macadamia nut pancakes -- nuff said. Misses: Parking not available. Long wait. No reservations.

properties.name: Byodo-In Temple
properties.description: Posted by Igrok KahaluuExact replica of the original in Japan. It commemorates the first Japanese immigrants to Hawaii.

properties.name: Chinatown
properties.description: Posted by Igrok  HonoluluHawaii\'s version of China in microcosm. It\'s quite a motley of intrigues; however, be aware that Chinatown is also the dumping grounds for your less than desirable locals (including a wench who doesn\'t shy from urinating in the street before your gawking eyes) -- hustling has gone casual here. Every Chinese New Year welcomes luck during which feting parades scare away evil spirits. Recommendations: Maunakea St for inexpensive leis (you can also watch workers make them). Cafe Oriente on Maunakea St, in my opinion, has the best food at an affordable price, and they even allow you to bring your own drinks (I suggest a quick fix at the convenience store next door where Sam Adams and Miller Lites can be purchased 3 for .44). If you\'re still married to Dim Sum, this is where your heart is.

properties.name: Diamond Head (Lē'ahi)
properties.description: Posted by Igrok  Waikiki, HIThe Legendary backdrop to all our imaginings of Hawaii.

properties.name: Dole Cannery
properties.description: Posted by Igrok  Iwilei Rd, HonoluluMy first job in HI was with the Honolulu Symphony Society located in the recently refurbished business offices at Dole Cannery. My primary tasks consisted of obeying every command issued from the Interim President, Gideon Toeplitz. We got along rather well, and subsequently I was invited to attend a backstage performance at the Blaisdell Center for free. Meetings were typified by escalating tiffs more akin to immature children unleashing a furious tantrum. Unabated, the program is nearing ground zero. Recommendations: Regal Theaters located right across the street is almost never as busy as downtown theaters and *shhh* the overhead showtime board in the main makes chain-viewing a simplistic maneuver.

properties.name: Dole Plantation
properties.description: Posted by Igrok  64-1550 Kamehameha HwyAll I can say is... pineapple ice-cream. Can I get a YUM YUM up in herr please! Plus, the World\'s Largest Hedge Maze -- cool! And, while you\'re at it, send a fresh Hawaiian pineapple to a deserving friend on the mainland. Cost is approx 5.

properties.name: Duke's Canoe Club
properties.description: Posted by Igrok  Waikiki, OahuThis restaurant evokes the quintessential Waikiki experience and is themed around the legendary Hawaii sports icon, Duke Kahanamoku, who is attributed to making Surf a global phenomenon. They have a rather limited menu -- mostly local catch -- but the salad bar\'s pretty decent. You\'re bound to feel Blue Hawaii nostaligic as you come under the spell of the musical female trio that wanders from table to table playing Hawaiian-tinged diddies. Best Feature: It\'s right on the beach. Recommendations: Make reservations (aiming for a time right before sunset)! Otherwise, brace yourself for a very long wait. Drinks are off tha chain!

properties.name: Haleiwa
properties.description: Posted by Igrok Historic surf town

properties.name: Hanauma Bay
properties.description: Posted by Igrok  Southeast OahuSpectacular snorkeling within the sunken crater of an extinct volcano.

properties.name: Hawaii Medical Services Assoc (HMSA)
properties.description: Posted by Igrok818 Keeaumoku St, Honolulu, HIWhere I\'ve been working since Oct 2005.

properties.name: Hawaii Theater Center
properties.description: Posted by Igrok  1130 Bethel St, HonoluluHistoric theater :: "Pride of the Pacific" :: Attended the 2005 Louis Vuitton International Film Festival at this venue. Tragically, the prehistoric audio system garbled chunks of the dialogue. Repulse the monkey!

properties.name: Hickam Air Force Base Terminal
properties.description: Posted by IgrokMilitary Installation

properties.name: Honolulu International Airport
properties.description: Posted by Igrok300 Rogers Blvd, Honolulu 96819

properties.name: Iolani School
properties.description: Posted by Igrok Honolulu, OahuThis private school happens to be one of the most expensive on the island but yearly churns out the most National Merit Scholars than any other school in Hawaii. I came here to see John Hope Franklin, the authority on African-American history, give a speech. He\'s 90 yrs old, so obviously no extraordinary oration!

properties.name: Japanese Cultural Center of Hawaii
properties.description: Posted by Igrok  2454 S Beretania St, HonoluluAll things Japanese, go figure.

properties.name: Kaneohe Post Office
properties.description: Posted by IgrokKaneohe Post OfficePO Box 1100 Kaneohe, HI 96744

properties.name: Kapi'olani Community College
properties.description: Posted by IgrokHonolulu, OahuI swear this has got to be the most beautiful community college campus I\'ve ever seen. I went to the 2006 Hawaii TESOL (Teach English as a Second Language) Conference and have since laid out plans to achieve my latest career goal. Best advice: Use Skype!

properties.name: Kapi'olani Park
properties.description: Posted by Igrok  Honolulu, OahuSpacious park located at the foot of Diamond Head. It was here where the May 6, 2006 celebration, "Salute to the Troops" was held. During the free festivities, I watched a military parade comprised of troops recently returned from Iraq and even shook hands with Governor Linda Lingle. Most notably, I experienced the visceral music prodigy that is John Legend (who graciously performed for 1.5 hrs)! Good times were had.

properties.name: Koa Pancake House
properties.description: Posted by Igrok 46-126 Kahuhipa St, KaneohePancakes and omelettes to die for! Don\'t leave here w/o sampling the exotic array of local syrups: pineapple/orange and coconut varieties. Waiting list can be quite long but not nearly as bad as Boots and Kimo\'s.

properties.name: Likelike Drive-In
properties.description: Posted by Igrok745 Keeaumoku St, Honolulu\'Ono kine local breakfast. I\'m a big fan of the loco moco and heavy-malted waffle.

properties.name: Liliha Bakery
properties.description: Posted by IgrokN Kuakini St, HonoluluA local favorite. Come get your scrumptiousdiddiliumptious coco puffs with chantilly on top! Portuguese malasadas!

properties.name: Matsumoto's Shave Ice
properties.description: Posted by Igrok 66-087 Kamehameha Hwy, Haleiwa 96712World\'s Most Famous Shave Ice

properties.name: National Memorial Cemetery of the Pacific
properties.description: Posted by Igrok PunchbowlThe Hawaiian name, "Puowaina," loosely means "Hill of Sacrifice."

properties.name: Outrigger Reef on the Beach
properties.description: Posted by Igrok    Waikiki, Oahu(27 April - 01 May \'06) Where my sister and her family stayed while on vacation. On the first floor we dined at the exquisite Ocean House, where fresh catch is prepared. I ordered seafood laulau, and sister was able to get the popular opah. It was all good.

properties.name: Pali Lookout
properties.description: Posted by Igrok   Ko\'olau Mountains, OahuGet gobsmacked as you look down upon an indescribable panorama of pristine waters, lush rainforest, steep cliffs (pali), and dormant volcanoes. This place was also site of a fierce battle between the armies of Kamehameha I and Kalanikupule, an alii nui (chief) of Maui and Oahu. Kamehameha\'s troops ultimately overpowered his rival\'s ending with their complete demise as they were all pushed off the sheer cliff.

properties.name: Pinoy House
properties.description: Posted by Igrok 45-168 William Henry Road, Kaneohe, HI 96744My first physical address in HI from 7 Sept \'05 - 7 Jan \'06.

properties.name: Polynesian Cultural Center
properties.description: Posted by Igrok  Laie, OahuProbably the best I\'ve seen. The Center is operated by BYU-Hawaii; purposefully, exchange students from the South Pacific earn their tuition by working as performers at the many themed isles. Activities are alternately scheduled (i.e. shows are usually 30 minutes long, and then right after the next 30 minutes are reserved for educational activities and exploratory walk). Recommendations: You can return the next day if you don\'t manage to finish all the exhibits. The luau is a bit artificial but satisfactory for first-timers, still if you decide to attend the grand finale performance later in the evening you\'ll more than get your fill of Magical Polynesia. Encore! Misses: Tickets are like, Whoa! 76044$

properties.name: Royal Mausoleum (Mauna 'Ala)
properties.description: Posted by Igrok Nuuanu Ave, HonoluluI chanced upon this tomb while wandering aimlessly after work at ACS. Some interesting facts: The grounds are considered Hawaiian soil and therefore will not raise an American flag. The interior of the small chapel is constructed of 100% Koa wood, an endemic tree found only in HI. The caretaker descends from a specific Hawaiian bloodline that traditionally inherits this post. Hawaiian Alii are buried and entombed on the premises, but the location of the remains of Kamehameha I\'s are still unknown.

properties.name: Sam Choy's
properties.description: Posted by Igrok N Nimitz Hwy, HonoluluAward-winning restaurant that specializes in Hawaiian regional cuisine. The chef has his own show and markets unique Hawaiian sauces... two thumbs way up!

properties.name: Shrimp Farms
properties.description: Posted by Igrok North Shore, OahuSooner or later along Kam(ehameha) Hwy you\'ll notice several sporadically placed shrimp shacks that farm these slick crustaceans. You can buy them live if you like, or you can have the cook prepare you a savory seafood platter.

properties.name: Statue of Kamehameha I
properties.description: Posted by Igrok Honolulu, OahuOn Kamehameha Day in June, this statue of the famous Hawaiian king is proudly adorned with long, draping leis thus creating a robe of orchids. In fact, a crane is needed in order for the leis to be properly bestowed.

properties.name: Tripler Army Medical Center
properties.description: Posted by Igrok  1 Jarrett White Road, HonoluluMore like a grand palace throned in glistening coral pink atop a juvenile mount, Tripler is quite the eye-catching yet classy "lass" par excellence. I\'m rather fond of breakfast re: gourmet omelettes for .

properties.name: USS Arizona Memorial
properties.description: Posted by Igrok Pearl Harbor, OahuOn 7 December 1941, the Japanese air fleet attacked Pearl Harbor inflicting more than 2.500 casualties. This memorial enshrines hope and reconciliation as former enemies annually meet on-site. The design implies initial defeat in the dip but bows upward at both ends symbolizing redemption and victory.

properties.name: Waimea Beach
properties.description: Posted by Igrok  North ShoreAzure waters baby!

properties.name: Waimea Valley
properties.description: Posted by Igrok   Now run by the Audubon Society, this leisurely park contains rare native and endangered flora and fauna including the elusive Alae \'Ula (red) bird, which has a deep red crown and in Hawaiian legend gave the Natives fire. At the end of the 3 mile trail is a refreshing waterfall; you\'re allowed to dip / swim in the pool. Come on in, the water\'s just fine!
